dialogue.text: There is no point.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's my point.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's my point too.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Then let's go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, wait no, no that's not my point.  My point is there is no point and coming all the way down here if we just turn around and go home.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Don't you want to see it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not particularly.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just don't, it's stupid.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's not stupid.  It's a natural phenomenon.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: People in Kansas would have to get plane tickets and make hotel reservations to see this.  It's only forty minutes away; it's just too good to pass up.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Pass what up?  These little fish swim out of the ocean, they flop around on the sand then they swim back and then they die.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah but that like flopping around is what to do it's like spawning or mating or something.  This is like the highlight of their little fish lives.  It's like life's last orgy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know what you're so excited about.  This isn't a moon landing we're talking about, it's fish, it's a fish nobody even eats.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, they do.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, Augie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, okay whatever, okay but it's a fish who do something that like no other fish do, you know, it's like those swallows that return to Capistrano or those like those lemmings that jumped off the cliffs, you know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's like a little bit of the unexplainable, a little magic, a little mystery.  I just don't see how you can not be interested in this.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For real?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't get it though, I mean the first time we came here you said it was like the best night of your life...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And last year I remember like distinctively you were so excited to get here that you didn't realize you stubbed your toe until we were in a car.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Last year, you'll also remember we got--our shoes got wet, I got sand in my panties, you got a sore throat, we got into a big fight and we did not see the grunions.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We just weren't in a good spot though.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We didn't see them the year before either.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We just weren't in a good spot I'm telling you this is a much better spot.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Come on, trust me I got instincts for these things, okay?  So just--just think about it all right?  Okay, I know you're not interested, think about it...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Out there, there's like this big mass of silver fish they're heading this way...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They don't know why, we don't know why.  No one like sent them an invitation or gave them a map or direction...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They just all turned at once and they just form this line as long as the California coast.  And they just started swimming...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Like some little time release fire cracker went off inside their little tiny bodies.  And they all turned as one...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And form the line and started swimming, swimming that would bring them to this point here...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's like urgency that's pure urge you know.  It's single-mindedness with no mind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's crazy.  Look at this, I'm giving myself goose bumps, the hairs are standing up on my arm.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's the wind.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why did he invite her here?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why does that bother you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's been in New York three and an half years, why all of a sudden?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well maybe...maybe he just wanted to see her.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Nobody comes seven hundred miles just to see.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do you mean?  You know he lived next door to the girl his whole life, why wouldn't he want to see her?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING] You don't look at me like that.  He didn't tell me anything more than he told you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's not going to marry her.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know he's even thinking about it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's got that about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh.  So what.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What is going on here, Joe?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Now listen.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She is not his girl.  She knows she's not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can't read her mind.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Then why is she still single?  New York is full of men, why is she still single?  Probably a hundred people told her she's foolish, but she waited.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know why she waited?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because she knows what I know, that's why.  She's faithful as a rock.  In my darkest moments, I think of her waiting and I know that I'm right.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey look, it's a nice day, huh?  Why are we arguing?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Nobody in this house dares take away her faith, Joe.  You know strangers might, but not his father, not his brother.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do you want me to do? What do you want?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I want you to-- I want you to act like he is coming back, both of you.  Don't think I haven't noticed you since Chris invited her here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I won't stand for any nonsense.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Kate.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because if he's not coming back, I'll kill myself.  Oh laugh, laugh all you like but why does this happen the very night he comes back.  She goes to sleep in his room and his memorial breaks in pieces.  Look at it, Joe, look.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just believe with me, Joe. Only last week a man came back in Detroit missing longer than Larry.  Believe with me. You, above all, have got to believe. Just believe.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay. Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know. All right, all right. All right. Okay.  Calm yourself. What does that mean, me above all?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look at you, you're shaking.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can't help it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What have I got to hide?  What the hell is the matter with you, Kate?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're the only one who still loves his parents.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  It kind of went out of style, didn't it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's not so bad; it's a good thing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING] You know, it's lovely here.  The air is sweet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're not sorry you came.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm not sorry, no. But I'm...I can't stay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For one thing, your mother much as told me to go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And then, you.  You've been kind of...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sort of embarrassed ever since I got here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well I was kind of planning of sneaking up on you over the course of a week or so.  They just take it for granted that we're all set.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I knew they would.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You did?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well sure, from your mother's point of view.  Why else would I come?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So would you want to?  I mean, I guess you have to know that's kind of why I asked you to come?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I, umm. I guess, I guess that's kind of why I came.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I love you. Annie, I love you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't really have any imagination, that's all I know how to say.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Am I embarrassing you? Are you - See, I didn't want to do it here with this yard, on this porch.  I wanted it to be somewhere new, some place fresh for both of us.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No. No

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You feel uncomfortable here, you feel that it's wrong here somehow.  I just...I don't...I didn't want...I didn't want to take you away from anything.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Chris, I've been ready a long, long, time.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And he's gone forever?  Are you sure?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I almost got married two years ago.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why didn't you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You started to write me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You felt something that far back?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Every day since.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why didn't you let me know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I was waiting for you, Chris.  You sure can be ambiguous, you know.  And when you did finally write me,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Give me a...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Give me a kiss.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God.  I kissed you Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: beating around the bush.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I will never forgive you.  All I'd done was sit around wondering if I was crazy waiting so long, wondering if you were thinking about me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh Annie, we are going to live now.  I am going to make you so happy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not like that you're not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I kissed you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like Larry's brother.  Do it like you, Chris.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Chris, what is it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey, let's drive some place.  Huh?  Let's get out of here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No. What is it?  Is it your mother?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No it's nothing like that. It's-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Then what?  Chris.  Even in your letters, there was something ashamed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  I suppose I have been. But it's going from me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You've got to tell me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't even know how to start.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It wouldn't work like this.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just all mixed up with so many other things, you know?  You know overseas I was in command of a company?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, sure.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well I lost them.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How many?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Pretty much all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Aw, geez.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can't just toss off a thing like that because they weren't just men. You know?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Like for instance, there was this one time it had been raining for several days and this kid he just came up to me and he gave me his last pair of dry socks.  He just put them in my pocket.  That's a little thing, you know, but that's what kind of guys I had.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They didn't die, they killed themselves for each other.  I mean that, exactly.  Just a little more selfish and they would all be here today.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I had this idea as I was watching them go down.  Everything was being destroyed, you know, but this one thing was being made.  It was kind of a monument, it's kind of responsibility, man for man.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Mmhmm.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To bring that on to the earth again, you know, is like some kind of monument and I thought I would just make a difference to them.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But then I came home and it was incredible, you know?  The whole thing was just kind of this random bus accident.  You know, I went back to the rat race again, I went to work.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Driving my new car and seeing a new refrigerator.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean...You can't take those things out of a war. when you drive that car and you see that new refrigerator, you have to know that it came out of the love that a man can have for another man.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I didn't want any of it. I guess that included you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you still feel that way?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just want you to know Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because you mustn't feel that way.  Everything you have, you've earned - everything.  you understand me?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Even me.  And your money?  Chris, there's nothing wrong in your money.  Your father put hundreds of planes into the air, you should be proud of that.  A man should be paid for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Annie, Annie.  I am going to make a fortune for you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What would I do with a fortune?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's he going to say?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Maybe we should tell him before he sees it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He saw it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How could he see it?  I was the first one up; he was still in bed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He was out here when it broke.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: When?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Four o clock this morning.  I heard a crack and I woke up and looked out.  He was standing right over there when it cracked.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What was he doing out here at four o clock in the morning?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's dreaming of him again, walking around.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess he is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's getting to be just like after he died.  What's the meaning of that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know the meaning of it.  But I know one thing, Mom, you've made a terrible mistake with father.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Being dishonest with him, you know.  This kind of thing always pays off and it's paying off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean dishonest?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know Larry is not coming back and I know it.  Why do we allow him to go on thinking that we believe with him?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you want to do?  Argue with him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't want to argue but it's time he realized that nobody believes Larry is alive.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know?  Why shouldn't he walk the nights thinking of him, dreaming of him?   Do we contradict him?  Do we say, we don't have any hope anymore?  That we haven't had any hope for years now?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't say that to him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We've got to say it to him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Where's the proof?  Do you have any proof?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For God's sake, three years?  Nobody comes back after three years; that's insane.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: To you it is, to me it is, but to your father, you can talk yourself until you are blue in the face.  But there is no grave and there is no body, so where are you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sit down, Mom.  I want to talk to you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's that the trouble is those God damn newspapers.  Every month some new boy comes back and so the next one is going to be Larry, they just--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right, all right, all right.  You know why I asked Annie here, right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I got an idea, but what's your story?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm going to ask her to marry me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well that's only your business, Chris.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know it's not just my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well what do you want me to do?  You're old enough to know your own mind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So all right then, I'll just go ahead with it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well you want to make sure that your father is not going to --

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then it's not just my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just saying.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know sometimes you infuriate me.  you know that?  Isn't it your business if I tell father and he throws a fit about it?  God, you have such a talent for ignoring things.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh.  I ignore what I got to ignore.  That girl is Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She's not Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: From your father's point of view, he is not dead and- Chris he still thinks he's still alive.  The girl is Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Now you can go on from there if you know where to go, but I'm telling you, I don't know where to go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know why it is, but every time I reach out for something I have to pull back because I am afraid other people will suffer. My whole bloody life, time after time.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're a considerate fellow, there's nothing wrong in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To hell with that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just don't see why.  Have you asked Annie yet?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wanted to get this settled first.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well how do you know she's going to marry you?  Maybe she feels the same way your father does.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well if she does, then that's it.  That's the end of it.  From her letters, though, I think she's pretty much forgotten him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And then we'll thrash it out with father.  Okay Mom?  Don't avoid me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The trouble is you don't see enough women.  You never did.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what.  I'm not fast with women.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why does it have to be Annie?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh that's a great reason.  It's no reason at all.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You haven't seen her since you went away to war, it's been five years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I can't help it, I know her best.  I was brought up next door to her, you know?  These years when I think of someone for my wife, I think of Annie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mom, what do you want?  A diagram?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't want a diagram.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He thinks he's coming back Chris.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You marry that girl, you are pronouncing him dead...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: ...and then what's that going to do to your father?  Do you know?  I don't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right, then, Mom. [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just give it some more thought.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've given it three years of thought.  And I'd hope that if I waited, father would forget about Larry and then we could just have a regular wedding and everyone would be happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But if I can't do that here, I may have to go somewhere else.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll get out.  I'll get married and I'll move somewhere else, maybe New York.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Are you crazy?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've been a good son for too long, a good sucker.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You have a business here.  What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The business?  The business doesn't inspire me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh.  Must you be inspired?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  I like it for an hour a day.  I don't care if I have to grub for money all day long, when I come home I want it happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want some kids, I want a family, I want somebody that I can give myself to and Annie is in the center of that.  Now it's just where to find it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You mean to tell me that you would leave the business over this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: On this, I would.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well you don't want to think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: All right.  But you don't want to think like that because what the hell are we working for, Chris?  It's all for you.  This whole shooting match is for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know that.  Then just help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just don't think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well I am thinking like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't understand you, do I?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  You don't.  I'm a pretty tough guy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can see that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look at this, all of the hairs are standing up on my arm.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's the wind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, so, what do you think?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: About what?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: About what I was saying.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I think it's ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It certainly is not.  It's slightly exaggerated scientific fact.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's PR! Somebody sold you a bunch of crap that there is this wonderful thing that is going to happen tonight on the beach.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Not just me, look at all of these people.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Everybody's told the same story.  It keeps us coming back for more, it keeps us excited.  We keep thinking that life is going start at any minute if we can just find the right spot, get in on the action.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are we talking about the same thing, here?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, it's just fish to me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Carla, can I ask you something?  Now, don't take this the wrong way, but are you on your period?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't ask me that.  I hate it when you ask me that, you always ask me that.  It's insulting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well then, what's bugging you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We just have different ideas of what this night is supposed to look like.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There is nothing to it; we come down here, the fish arrive, they flop around, they do their fish thing.  We go ooh, ah, look at the fish and we go home.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For God- Grow up, Augie.  The fish are not going to arrive.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because they never do.  Have they...Have they ever?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We've missed them twice.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Twice is every time we have tried; that's ever.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.text: You know, the trouble is you've never had enough women. No, you never did.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what? I'm not fast with women.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't understand why it has to be her.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's a good answer, but it doesn't answer anything.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, you haven't seen her since the war. I mean, it's been five years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It just is. I-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I grew up with her. Okay. All these years, when I think of someone I want to be my wife I think of Annie. What do you want, a diagram?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, I don't want a diagram.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He thinks he's coming back. You go-go on and marry her, I mean, you're pronouncing her dead. And what's going to happen to your father, huh? I don't know. Do you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay. All right, then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just, listen. Give it more thought, is all.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I've given it three years of thought.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I thought that if I waited then dad would forget about Larry and then we could have a regular wedding and everything happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But if I can't have that here then I'll get out.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll get out. I'll marry her somewhere else. Maybe New York.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're crazy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've been a sucker too long. I'm through with it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're what-you're going to leave the business? But you can't do that. What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The business. The business doesn't inspire me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, you have to be inspired.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes. I like it an hour out of the day. If I have to grub for money all day long at least that evening I want it beautiful. I want a wife. I want a family. I want some kids. I want to build something I can give myself to.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Now, Annie's in the middle of all that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Now, where do I find it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Tell me something.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You'd leave that business.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes. On this I would.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't do that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: All right, but you can't do that. You can't talk like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay. Just-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We've worked all our lives for you. Only for you, Chris. The whole shootin' match is for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, I know, I know, just help me stay here, all right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm going to.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You just can't talk like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I am thinking like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know you, do I?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, you don't. I'm a pretty tough guy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah. I can see that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Good God.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you think it's them?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wonder.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, nobody knows we're here except for Freda and she wouldn't ring up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It must be them then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What are we to do?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We're all right, aren't we darling? Whatever happens.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes. Now and always, sweet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then I don't care.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It was bound to come sooner or later.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hello? Hello? What? Ugh, wrong number.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] God, it sent shivers up my spine.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: things that should matter dreadfully don't seem to matter at all when one's happy, do they?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Um terrible thing is one can't stay happy. Well, it's true. I mean, the whole business is a very poor joke.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ooh darling, don't say that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You mean that sacred and beautiful thing, love?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, meaning just that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What does it all mean? That's what I ask myself in my quest for ultimate truth. What does it all mean?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't laugh at me. I'm serious.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]. You mustn't be serious, my dear one, that's what they want.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Who's they?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All the futile moralists who try to make life unbearable. Laugh at them. Be flippant. Laugh at all the sacred shibboleths. Flippancy brings out the acid in their damn sweetness and light.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, if I laugh at everything I'm going to have to laugh at us too.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ooh, certainly you must. We're figures of fun, all right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So how long is it going to last? This ludicrous, overbearing love of ours?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Who knows?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Shall we always want to bicker and fight?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No. The fire will fade along with our passion.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh dear, well, shall we want that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Depends on how well we play it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, what if happens if one of us is to die? Does the one that's left still laugh?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, yes. Yes, he must with all his might.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, that's serious enough.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No. No, it isn't. Death's very laughable. A cunning little mystery. All done with mirrors.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Darling, I believe you're talking nonsense.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So is everyone else in the long run. Let's be superficial and pity the poor philosophers.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Let's blow strumpets, blow-blow trumpets and squeakers and party as much as we can like small quite idiotic school children. Let's savor the delight of the moment. Come, kiss me darling, before worms pop in and out of your eye sockets.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Elliott, worms don't pop.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't care what you do, see? As long-you can paint yourself bright green all over and dance naked in the Place Vendome and rush off madly with all the men in the world and I shan't say a word as long as you love me best.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Thank you, dear. The same applies to you. Except that if I ever so much as catch you looking at another woman I'll kill you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Remember that awful scene we had in Venice?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Which particular one?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The one when you bought that little painted wooden snake in the Piazza and put it in my bed.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh Charles. That was his name. Charles. He did wiggle so beautifully.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Horrible little thing. I hated it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know you did. You threw it out the window and into the Grand Canal. I don't think I'll ever forgive you for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How long did that row last?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It went on intermittently for days.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The worst one was in Cannes when your-your curling iron burnt a hole in my dressing gown.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I burnt a hole in my comb too, and all the towels in the bathroom. [LAUGHTER].

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: yeah. And that was the first time you ever hit me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That was a rouser, wasn't it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The manager came in and found us rolling on the floor and biting and scratching like panthers. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I didn't hit you very hard.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know. Oh man. Couldn't believe it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, I will never forget his face. Ooh-rah [LAUGHTER].

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We were very much younger then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, and very much sillier.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, the real cause of that row was Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: As a matter of fact, the real cause of that row was Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You knew there was nothing in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I knew nothing of the sort. You took presents from him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Presents? It was only a small trivial little broach.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I remember it well. Bristling with diamonds. In the worst possible taste.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not at all. It was very pretty. And I wear it all the time. I still have it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You went out of your way to torture me over Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, I didn't. You made that up all in your jealous imagination.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You must admit that he was in love with you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just a little perhaps, but it was nothing serious.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You let him kiss you. You said so.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, what of it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What of it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh come on, it gave him a lot of pleasure and it didn't harm me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What about me?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, if you hadn't been so suspicious and nosey you'd have never known anything about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's a nice point of view, I must say.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, it's true.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are you bored with this conversation?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I definitely, most definitely am.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So am I. Bored stiff. Want some brandy?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, thanks.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll have a little, I think.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't see why you want it; you've already had two glasses.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No particular reason. Anyhow, they were very small ones.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't see what's the point of going on and on about something like this.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, my-you can hardly call three minute liquor glasses in the evening going on and on and on.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's become a habit with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You needn't be so grand just because you don't happen to want some yourself at the moment.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't be so stupid.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Really, Amanda.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Nothing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Going somewhere, dear?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No. Just making myself fascinating for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That reply has broken my heart.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's a woman's job to allure the man. Watch me, won't you, a minute?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: As a matter of fact, that's perfectly true.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, it isn't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, it's not. I don't care.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's a pity you didn't have more brandy. It might have made you a little less disagreeable.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, it didn't seem to do such wonders with you, now did it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, snap, snap, snap, like a little adder.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Adders don't snap, they sting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, they do. They have a big bag of venom behind their fangs and they snap.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They sting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They snap.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't care. I don't care, do you understand? I don't care if they bark, if they roll over on the floor like hoops.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Uhh,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: did you see much of Peter Burden after our divorce?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, I did, quite a lot actually.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I imagine that you let him kiss you quite a bit more then, didn't you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Mind your business.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You had a riotous-must have had a riotous time. No restraint at all. Very enjoyable. You never had much anyhow.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You are quite insufferable. I suppose it's because you're drunk.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm not in the least bit drunk.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You've always had a weak head.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay. As I mentioned before, I said I had three very minute liquor glasses. That's hardly enough to get a child of two drunk.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: On the contrary, a child of two can get violently drunk on only one glass of brandy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, very interesting indeed. How about a child of four or a child of six or a child of nine. We might have a splendid little debate about this intemperate tots.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do shut up. Shut up.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't want to talk about this anymore.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You better turn that off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's very late and it will annoy the people upstairs.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There aren't any people upstairs. It's a photographer's studio.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, I suppose the people downstairs then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They're away in Tunis.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is no time of the year for Tunis.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Turn it on again, please.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I will do no such thing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Turn it on.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You've always had far too temperamental for yourself. You should try to control it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Turn it off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I will not. Go away. Go away. I hate you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, very amusing, indeed. Amanda, listen-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Listen, indeed. No, no, no, no. I am sick and tired of listening to you, you sadistic bully.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Very amusing indeed.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Stop it, stop it, I hate you, I loath you, you are overbearing and conceited and utterly impossible.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know, you're a vile, ill-tempered, wicked little beast and I hope that I never see you again as long as I live.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This is the end. Do you hear? The end. Now and forever.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, you're not going out like this. No you're not.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, yes I am.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes I am. Let go of me. I hate you and I loath you. God, I can't believe I just finally realized how you are. I am never marry you. Never. Never, never, never. I would rather die in torment.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, shut up. Shut up. Shut up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wouldn't marry you again if you came back crawling to me on your hands and knees because you're vile. You're a mean, evil-minded little vampire and I hope to God I never set eyes on you again.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Beast or brute cad, swine beast beast brute.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why did you invite her here?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why? Does that bother you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's been in New York for three-and-a-half years. She don't just suddenly come and-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, maybe, maybe he just wanted to see her.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You don't travel seven hundred miles just to see.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do you mean? They lived next door to each other their entire lives. Why shouldn't he want to see her? Hey, don't look at me like that. I don't know anymore than you do.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's not going to marry her.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know he's even thinking about it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's got that about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, so what?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's going on here, Joe?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Listen, kid-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's not Larry's girl. She knows that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can't read her mind.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Then why is she married? Then why isn't she married? She's been in New York and there's hundreds of single men there.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm sure hundreds of them asked her and told her that she's foolish, but no.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's waited.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know why she's waited?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because she thinks like me, that's why.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's faithful as a rock, don't you know. In my worst moments I can think of her-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I think again, that I'm-I'm right.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look, it's a nice day. What are we arguing for?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Nobody in my house better ever dare-dare to challenge her faith. Maybe strangers, but not his father, not his brother.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because he's not coming back. Then what do I got to live for? I'll kill myself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't, don't laugh at me, don't laugh at me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look at it. Because why, when she came here and she slept in his room, the memorial broke into pieces. Look at it, look at it, Joe.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right. All right. Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You got to believe, believe with me because I can't stand all alone.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay. Just calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, you've got to believe.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Believe, Joe. You above all people have got to believe.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why me, above all?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Huh?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why me above all?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You got to keep believing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look at you, you're shaking.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can't help it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What have I got to hide?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Huh? What the hell's the matter with you, Kate?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're the only one I know that still loves his parents.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  It sort of went out of style didn't it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  It's alright.  It's a good thing, you know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's lovely here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The air is so sweet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're not sorry you came?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  I'm not sorry.  But I'm not going to stay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: First of all your mother so much as told me to go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look,

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: you saw the way that she acted and then well, I mean, you, you were acting kind of...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I don't know, embarrassed of her since I came.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well the trouble is I was planning on sneaking up on you over a week or so and they take it for granted that we're all set.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  I know they would, especially your mother.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How did you know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well what other reason, from her point of view, would I be coming here?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So, would you want to?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean, that's the reason why I asked you here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh Annie.  I love you.  I love you a great deal.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I love you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I guess that's why I came.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't...I have no imagination that's the only way I know how to tell it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm embarrassing you.  I didn't want to tell you this here.  I wanted to drive someplace brand new where we'd be brand new to each other.  It feels wrong here don't you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This yard and this chair.  I don't want to win you from anything, I want you to be ready for me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, I've been ready for a long, long time now.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then he's gone forever, you sure?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, I almost got married two years ago.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why didn't you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You started to write me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You felt something that far back.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Every day since.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why didn't you let me know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I was waiting for you Chris, I mean, till then you never wrote and then when you did what did you say?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You'd always be so ambiguous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Give me a kiss Ann, just give me...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh God.  Annie, I kissed Annie.  I kissed Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'll never forgive you for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How long, how long I've been waiting to do that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean,  Why did you wait all these years?  There I was sitting around and wondering if I was crazy for thinking about you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We're going to live now.  I'm going to make you so happy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not like that you're not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I kissed you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like Larry's brother.  Do it like you Chris.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Nothing.  Hey, let's drive somewhere.  I want to be alone with you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What is it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, what is it?  Your mother?

dialogue.text: But why did that happen the very night she came back?  She goes to sleep in his bed and his memorial breaks in pieces.  Look at it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Believe with me, Joe.  I can't stand alone.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Only last week a man turned up in Detroit missing longer than Larry.  You read it yourself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right.  All right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You above all have got to believe.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do you mean, me above all?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just don't stop believing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What's that suppose to mean, me above all?  Look at you, you're shaking.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can't help it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What have I got to hide, Kate?  What the hell is the matter with you?
